title: What's involved in a PhD dissertation? - Quora

response.answer_text: The PhD dissertation is the culmination of an academic journey; it needs to reflect this. The school will have a guide to be followed, but basically you will select a topic, and get it approved. The methods used will need to be approved by your institution’s review board (IRB). In most schools, you will do a one page informal paper that reflects your idea, get the idea as a whole approved, and then write maybe a five page prospectus. Once it is approved the proposal is made, which consists of the first chapter of the thesis itself, the literature review, and the methodology. These are written in the future tense. Once this is approved (and you’ll probably have several edits first), you begin the ‘real’ work. You do the actual research, then write the results, findings, discussion, and conclusions (a total of 3–4 more chapters depending on the university). Expect multiple reviews and edits — some schools now want a chapter at a time, that must be approved before going on. Finally it is all approved, published, and done!
